10.questionText: Which of the following should you avoid to keep your bones healthy?
10.explanation: Processed foods tend to be too high in phosphorus, which can decrease bone density. Sugary and artificially sweetened drinks and caffeine can rob your body of minerals needed for healthy bones.

10.questionText: How many people over 50 are living with HIV in the UK?
10.explanation: More than a third of people accessing HIV care in the UK are now aged 50 years or above

10.questionText: Which of the following is a good way to improve your body image?
10.explanation: To feel more comfortable with your body, look in the mirror, find one thing about your body that you like and compliment yourself. If you do that every day, you'll have a host of positive statements to replace the negative self-talk that can get in the way of enjoying sex.

answers.answerText: Look in the mirror and compliment yourself.
Look at pictures of models in magazines.
Gain as much weight as you wish.

10.questionText: When is the best time to talk to your partner about your sexual needs?
10.explanation: The best time to communicate with your partner about your sexual needs is when you're outside the bedroom. Doing this brings your partner's defensiveness down. Another way to communicate with your partner is to each write down the things you've always wanted out of your sexual relationship and switch papers. Then meet and talk about it. Just be sure not to laugh, because you don't want your partner to feel embarrassed.

10.questionText: What is the leading cause of death in men?
10.explanation: Heart disease is the leading cause of death in American men. On average, more than 300,000 men die each year because of heart disease.

10.questionText: At what age does heart disease risk increase for men?
10.explanation: Men over the age of 45 are more likely to have coronary heart disease. However, that does not mean you should wait to be screened for heart disease until you're in your 40s. Blood tests and a physical examination each year may detect warning signs of the killer disease before it's taken a toll on your body.

10.questionText: Which of the following activities can help you live longer?
10.explanation: Being active, learning to relax and making sure your blood pressure is in check can have a dramatic effect on your life expectancy and quality of life.

10.questionText: Which attitude can help you live longer?
10.explanation: An optimistic outlook can boost your immune system. One study found that people who had positive attitudes towards aging lived an average of seven and a half years longer than those who viewed aging in a negative manner.

10.questionText: What are foods that combat pain that comes from inflammation?
10.explanation: A study in the Journal of Nutrition showed that eating berries daily can significantly reduce inflammation.

10.questionText: Where could the pain under the shoulder blade be coming from?
10.explanation: Pain under the shoulder blade can actually be coming from other areas of the body, such as the gall bladder, heart, aorta, fallopian tubes, abdominal organs, diaphragm and lungs. An aggravated muscle could be sending pain to this area as well. See your physician if this symptom persists.

10.questionText: Why is back pain difficult to diagnose?
10.explanation: As common as back pain is, it's often difficult to diagnose what caused it because it greatly varies from person to person. Fortunately, pinpointing the exact cause of a back breakdown isn't the important thing, since most pain can be alleviated with the right therapy.

answers.answerText: Because pain and symptoms vary greatly from person to person
Because it's such a large area
Because we don't yet have the proper body scanners

10.questionText: At what age should a woman begin getting yearly mammogram screenings?
10.explanation: Mammograms are the most effective breast cancer screening tools today. According to the American Cancer Society, annual mammogram screenings are optional for women ages 40-44, and should be performed yearly during the ages of 45-54, then every other year after 55.

10.questionText: By what percentage can Meidterranean diet reduce Alzeihmer's?
10.explanation: Research shows eating a Mediterranean diet could reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease by up to 40 percent.

10.questionText: What is ovarian cancer's nickname?
10.explanation: Ovarian cancer has been called "the silent killer" because symptoms are often undetected, or ignored, until the cancer is in an advanced stage. In other words, the cancer is able to progress -- and become deadly -- almost without notice.

1.questionText: Whom did David Cameron succeed as the British prime minister?
1.explanation: Gordon Brown remained in office as Labour negotiated to form a coalition government with the Liberal Democrats. ... He was succeeded as Prime Minister by David Cameron

1.questionText: Complete the title of the play by Shakespeare – ‘The Merchant of …’?
1.explanation: The Merchant of Venice is a 16th-century play written by William Shakespeare in which a merchant in Venice named Antonio defaults on a large loan provided by a Jewish moneylender, Shylock. It is believed to have been written between 1596 and 1599

1.questionText: By what name is the TV adventurer Edward Michael Grylls more commonly known?
1.explanation: Edward Michael Grylls OBE, better known as Bear Grylls, is a British former SAS serviceman, survival instructor, and honorary lieutenant-colonel, and, outside his military career, an adventurer, writer, television presenter and businessman

1.questionText: Jollof rice, or jollof, is a one-pot rice dish popular in many countries in which part of Africa
1.explanation: Jollof rice is one of the most common dishes in West Africa. There are several regional variations in name and ingredients

2.questionText: Which of the following are symptoms of diabetes?
2.explanation: All of the above are symptoms of diabetes. Other symptoms include feeling tired all the time, slow-to-heal cuts and bruises, frequent colds and flu, unexplained weight loss, blurred vision and a numbness or tingling pain in the feet or hands.

2.questionText: What are the ABCs of diabetes?
2.explanation: Know your ABCs: A1c, blood pressure and cholesterol levels. Lowering your A1c, which is your average blood glucose level in the last two to three months, by just one point can reduce your risk for diabetes complications by 40 percent.

answers.answerText: Average heart beat, blood pressure and cholesterol
Average blood glucose level, blood pressure and cholesterol
Appetite, blood sugar and cholesterol level

2.questionText: A person's healthcare expenses typically increase by what percent after a diabetes diagnosis?
2.explanation: Research shows that if you have diabetes, your healthcare costs will likely increase by at least 2 percent.

2.questionText: Depression increases the risk of diabetes by how much?
2.explanation: Depression can increase the risk of diabetes by 60 percent. That's because people who are depressed often don't exercise and/or eat right -- both of which can boost the odds of developing diabetes. Research also links depression with hormonal changes that can raise a person's risk for obesity and diabetes.

3.questionText: What is a diabetes-related sexual complication in women?
3.explanation: About half of all adults are likely to develop some form of diabetes-related sexual complication. Men may have erectile dysfunction, premature ejaculation and low testosterone, while women may experience vaginal dryness, low sex drive and painful intercourse. Keeping blood sugar at a healthy level, lowering blood pressure and getting regular exercise can all help improve sexual function.

3.questionText: Walking at what time of day can help lower blood glucose levels?
3.explanation: A study found that walking after a meal helps lower blood glucose levels better than a pre-supper stroll. It's a great way to end the day -- and it's good for your blood suga

answers.answerText: In the morning, before your day has started.

3.questionText: When should people with diabetes check their blood sugar when it comes to exercise?
3.explanation: Workouts under 45 minutes: Check your blood sugar before you exercise, immediately afterward and again later, as exercise can affect blood glucose levels for up to 12 hours. Workouts longer than 45 minutes: Check your blood sugar during the workout as well. If you're on medication to control blood sugar and your workouts routinely cause low blood sugar, a doctor may need to adjust your dosage.

answers.answerText: It depends on the length of the workout.

3.questionText: Which of these seasonings can help your heart?
3.explanation: A powerful flavonoid found in all of these seasonings appears to hinder the production of compounds that trigger inflammation. That's great news for your heart, because inflammation increases your chances of heart disease. Other foods that fight inflammation are celery, fish oil, nuts, pineapple and leafy greens.

3.questionText: Which of these dairy foods protects women's hearts?
3.explanation: Studies show older women who eat at least half a cup of yogurt each day have a heart-protective edge over non-yogurt eaters. The women who eat yogurt have better arterial health, and they have higher levels ofhigh-density lipoproteins. It's thought that the healthy bacteria in yogurt might keep triglycerides and blood pressure low.

answers.answerText: Both of Yogurt and Low fat milk

3.questionText: Which of these fish is best for getting heart-healthy omega-3 fatty acids?
3.explanation: Of these three options, anchovies are the best for getting heart-healthy omega-3 fatty acids. These pint-sized fish don't spend as much time growing before they're caught, so they don't have a lot of exposure to mercury in the water. Swordfish and mahi-mahi, both very large and long-living fish, do, so their levels of mercury tend to be very high -- dangerous, even. Resources like the Monterey Bay Aquarium can help you pick eco-friendly, sustainable and lower-mercury fish options.

4.questionText: To improve your heart health, how many calories do you need to burn each week by exercising?
4.explanation: Burning just 1,000 calories each week gives your heart a helping hand and improves your cardiovascular health. This practice can significantly lower the risk of heart disease. Exercise of all kinds is great for your heart. Walk for 30 minutes several times a week, and you'll hit your 1,000-calorie mark.

4.questionText: By age 55, if you've never had high blood pressure, what percent chance do you have of developing it?
4.explanation: Research suggests that by age 55, those who don't already have high blood pressure face a 90 percent chance of developing the condition in their lifetime.

4.questionText: Having high blood pressure increases your risk for which of these conditions?
4.explanation: All of the above. Hypertension greatly increases your likelihood of stroke, aneurysm (a bulge in the wall of a blood vessel or the heart), heart failure, heart attack, kidney damage and other problems.

4.questionText: Which of these diets has been shown to help lower and control high blood pressure?
4.explanation: The DASH, or Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension, diet is chock full of the fruits, vegetables, whole grains, vitamins and minerals that are proven to lower high blood pressure. The DASH diet also recommends 30 minutes of exercise each day, another proven way to help lower high blood pressure.

4.questionText: Eating which of these breakfast foods may help lower your blood pressure?
4.explanation: In one study, a diet supplemented with oats was effective at slashing blood pressure readings and helped control cholesterol and blood sugar. To get the amount of oats the study participants got, you need only about three-fourths of a cup of whole-grain oatmeal at breakfast and an oat-based snack later in the day.

4.questionText: Enlarged prostate -- common in men in their 50s and 60s -- has been linked to erectile problems. What food can men eat to keep their prostate from becoming enlarged?
4.explanation: A compound in avocado called beta-sitosterol has been shown to decrease BPH. The major benefits: smaller prostate size and fewer nighttime awakenings for urinating. Saw palmetto is another source of beta-sitosterol.

5.questionText: Because menopause drastically reduces testosterone and estrogen, women in their 50s typically have a lower sex drive. What foods can increase a woman's libido?
5.explanation: Pumpkin seeds and oysters contain zinc, the ultimate sex mineral. Studies show that women with a greater sex drive have higher levels of testosterone—and zinc boosts testosterone production. Celery contains androsterone, a pheromone precursor. Once "smelled," pheromones can subconsciously affect the behavior of the receiving mate.

5.questionText: Which of the following things can contribute to a poor sex life in your 50s?
5.explanation: Factors inhibiting great sex include obesity, high blood sugar and clogged arteries. Getting half an hour of daily exercise and eating healthy foods helps.

5.questionText: Weakening pelvic-floor muscles can make sex less pleasurable for men and women as they age. What can men and women do?
5.explanation: Strengthen your pelvic muscles by doing Kegel exercises every day. While these exercises are especially recommended for women, they can benefit men, too.

5.questionText: In aging men, erectile difficulties often are caused by a combination of lack of testosterone and…
5.explanation: Nitric oxide, a chemical produced by healthy blood vessels, plays a large role in maintaining erections. The same factors that increase heart disease risk -- high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes -- reduce nitric oxide levels, making erections more difficult.

5.questionText: How often do sexually active older couples typically have intercourse?
5.explanation: Sexually active older couples have sex about six times a month, a frequency that continues into their nineties!

5.questionText: Which of these foods is an important part of the Mediterranean diet?
5.explanation: All of the above. A Mediterranean diet relies on olive oil, nuts, fruits, veggies, whole grains and fish for a wide range of fiber, healthy fats and antioxidants.

5.questionText: What kind of diet is best for bone health?
5.explanation: Opt for a colorful diet of fruits and vegetables, which are bursting with antioxidants called carotenoids. A four-year study found that older adults with the highest intakes of carotenoids retained more bone mineral density than those eating fewer fruits and veggies.

answers.answerText: Diet rich in fruits and vegetables

5.questionText: Calcium cannot be absorbed into your body without what other vitamin?
5.explanation: While calcium is extremely important for your bones and teeth, you also need adequate amounts of vitamin D, which helps your body absorb the calcium.

6.questionText: Which of the following should you make sure you eat to build strong bones?
6.explanation: Salmon is a good source of vitamin D and B12. Leafy greens like spinach provide magnesium and vitamin K, two important helpers when it comes to building bone. Bananas are one of the best sources of potassium around. And studies have found that potassium lovers have stronger skeletons

6.questionText: Older patients with HIV face a number of factors that affect their quality of life including…
6.explanation: None

6.questionText: What are the social issues that Black Africans aged 50 years and over are likely to experience?
6.explanation: Social , stigma, isolation is common among older people from minority ethnic groups who are living with HIV

6.questionText: What is arthritis?
6.explanation: Arthritis is inflammation in and around the body's joints.

answers.answerText: Inflammation in and around the body's joints
" An infection in the body's joints"

6.questionText: Which of these is the most common form of arthritis?
6.explanation: Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis. It's a condition in which the cartilage that covers the bones and forms the surface of the joints becomes thinner, rougher and less protective of the bone. As that happens, the bones grind against each other, and the joint becomes inflamed.

6.questionText: Which of these is a symptom of arthritis?
6.explanation: All of the above. Pain, stiffness and swelling can result from inflammation associated with arthritis.

6.questionText: What is the world's most populated country?
6.explanation: China, officially the People's Republic of China, is a country in East Asia and the world's most populous country, with a population of around 1.428 billion in 2017.

6.questionText: What is the capital city of Zambia?
6.explanation: Lusaka is the capital and largest city of Zambia. One of the fastest developing cities in southern Africa, Lusaka is in the southern part of the central plateau at an elevation of about 1,279 metres (4,196 ft). As of 2010, the city's population was about 1.7 million, while the urban population is 2.4 million

6.questionText: What is the World's Smallest Country?
6.explanation: Vatican City officially Vatican City State is an independent city-state[9] enclaved within Rome, Italy. Established with the Lateran Treaty (1929), it is distinct from, yet under "full ownership, exclusive dominion, and sovereign authority and jurisdiction" of the Holy See.

6.questionText: In which country can you find the Victoria Fall?
6.explanation: Victoria Falls is a waterfall in southern Africa on the Zambezi River at the border between Zambia and Zimbabwe

6.questionText: In which country is the Cape of Good Hope?
6.explanation: The Cape of Good Hope is a rocky headland on the Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula in South Africa. A common misconception is that the Cape of Good Hope is the southern tip of Africa.

6.questionText: Which of the following contributes to heartburn?
6.explanation: All of the above. Additionally, stress, smoking and certain foods may cause heartburn.

7.questionText: Which of these countries uses the Shilling as its currency?
7.explanation: The shilling (1/-) was a coin worth one twentieth of a pound sterling, or twelve pence. It was first minted in the reign of Henry VII as the testoon, and became known as the shilling from the Old English scilling, sometime in the mid-16th century, circulating until 1990 in th UK

7.questionText: In which ocean is the island of Madagascar?
7.explanation: Madagascar, officially the Republic of Madagascar, and previously known as the Malagasy Republic, is an island country in the Indian Ocean, approximately 400 kilometres off the coast of East Africa. At 592,800 square kilometres Madagascar is the world's 2nd largest island country

7.questionText: Who or what is Liberia's capital Monrovia named after?
7.explanation: Monrovia is named in honor of U.S. President James Monroe, a prominent supporter of the colonization of Liberia and the American Colonization Society. Along with Washington, D.C., it is one of two national capitals to be named after a U.S. President

answers.answerText: James Monroe, the fifth president of the United States
Monroe trees, indigenous to the region

7.questionText: Who was the first person convicted by the international criminal court?
7.explanation: Thomas Lubanga Dyilo is a convicted war criminal from the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the first person ever convicted by the International Criminal Court. He founded and led the Union of Congolese Patriots and was a key player in the Ituri conflict.

answers.answerText: The architect of apartheid Hendrik Verwoerd
Former British prime minister Tony Blair

7.questionText: How many black presidents have there been in South Africa?
7.explanation: After the end of the infamous apartheid rule in 1994, South Africa has had five presidents with Nelson Mandela being the first post-apartheid president

7.questionText: Which country is often referred to as the 'Giant of Africa', owing to its large population and economy?
7.explanation: Nigeria is the world's 20th largest economy as of 2015, worth more than $500 billion and $1 trillion in terms of nominal GDP and purchasing power parity, respectively. It overtook South Africa to become Africa's largest economy in 2014.

7.questionText: Timbuktu is in which country?
7.explanation: Timbuktu is a very real city located in the West African country of Mali. It is an exotic location, though. and is home to approximately 50,000 people. Timbuktu is best known for its famous Djinguereber Mosque and prestigious Sankore University, both of which were established in the early 1300s under the reign of the Mali Empire, most famous ruler, Mansa Musa

7.questionText: Today, the term Greater Maghreb corresponds roughly to which 16th to 19th century region?
7.explanation: Barbary Coast is the term used by Europeans until the 19th century to refer to the coastal regions of what is now Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya.

7.questionText: The Republic of the Congo became independent from which country in 1960?
7.explanation: The Belgian Congo achieved independence on 30 June 1960 under the name Republic of the Congo. Congolese nationalist Patrice Lumumba was elected the first Prime Minister, while Joseph Kasa-Vubu became the first President.

7.questionText: Who was Ethiopia's regent from 1916 to 1930, and Emperor from 1930 to 1974?
7.explanation: Haile Selassie I was Crown Prince and Regent of the Ethiopian Empire from 1916 to 1928, and then King and Regent from 1928 to 1930, and finally Emperor from 1930 to 1974. He is a defining figure in modern Ethiopian history.

7.questionText: Kano and Abuja are two large cities in which country?
7.explanation: The ancient city of Kano is the second largest city in Nigeria. It is also the largest Northern city in the country. Abuja, city, capital of Nigeria. It lies in the central part of Nigeria, in the Federal Capital Territory

7.questionText: Kofi Annan, the seventh Secretary-General of the United Nations from 1997 to 2006, is what nationality?
7.explanation: Kofi Atta Annan was a Ghanaian diplomat who served as the seventh Secretary-General of the United Nations from January 1997 to December 2006. Annan and the UN were the co-recipients of the 2001 Nobel Peace Prize

7.questionText: What are the origins of the name 'Africa'? The name has its origins in a small country in the North of Africa (Tunisia) and it mean…
7.explanation: The name 'Africa' has its origins in an ancient area of Tunisia called Ifriqiya which roughly translates to 'sunny place'

8.questionText: What is the name of the fast food dish popular in South Africa which is made by filling a hollowed-out loaf of bread with curry?
8.explanation: Bunny Chow. Also known as a kota or 'quarter'.

8.questionText: Which country is Africa'a most popular tourist destination?
8.explanation: Egypt is Africa's top tourist destination which is not surprising when you remember that it is home to world famous attractions like the Great Sphinx of Giza, and the tomb of Tutankhamun at Luxor.

8.questionText: To make chocolate you need cocoa beans. Approximately how much of the world's cocoa bean crop is grown in West Africa?
8.explanation: 66% .... with Ivory Coast alone being responsible for about 30% of the world's cocoa supply. (Always check it's Fair Trade

8.questionText: How often should people aged 50 and over, go for cancer screening?
8.explanation: "Cancer screening should be offered in accordance with recommendations i.e every 2 years in men and women aged 60–74 years; mammography every 3 years for breast cancer in women aged 50–70 years (earlier if indicated by family history"

8.questionText: Which of these might cause incontinence?
8.explanation: All of the above. Any of these may cause incontinence by putting pressure on the bladder, resulting in urine leakage.

8.questionText: In men, urinary incontinence can be caused by which of the following?
8.explanation: Prostate diseases like prostatitis, an enlarged prostate or prostate cancer can cause a loss of bladder control. However, incontinence can also be caused by bladder infections, bladder stones, stress or brain and spinal cord disorders.

8.questionText: What tests are used to diagnose incontinence?
8.explanation: A urinalysis can be analyzed for bacteria, blood or other abnormalities. An ultrasound, cystoscopy, or stress test might be advised as well.

8.questionText: Having low testosterone (low-T) levels can increase the risk of which of these conditions?
8.explanation: Men with low testosterone levels are more prone to being overweight, having diabetes or feeling fatigued and depressed. A simple blood test can help diagnose low-T.

8.questionText: Which of these is a symptom of low testosterone?
8.explanation: Men with low testosterone may experience infertility, sleeplessness and loss of interest in sex as well as anxiety, decrease in energy and erectile dysfunction.

8.questionText: What causes back pain?
8.explanation: All of the above. Most often back pain results from strained muscles and ligaments that surround the spine. Structural problems with the bones of the spine may also cause back pain.

answers.answerText: Structural problems with the bones of the spine

8.questionText: Which of the following is a risk factor for low-back pain?
8.explanation: All of the above. You're at risk for low-back pain if you've previously had it, are age 50 or older, are pregnant or obese, or have weak core muscles, arthritis or osteoporosis.

8.questionText: Which of these puts the equivalent of 100 extra pounds of stress on your lower back?
8.explanation: Bad posture can put the equivalent of 100 extra pounds of stress on your lower back.

answers.answerText: Driving for more than four hours

8.questionText: How many weeks does it take most people to fully recover from back pain?
8.explanation: Ninety-five percent of people are fully recovered from back pain in 12 weeks. Sixty percent are usually recovered in just 1 to 3 weeks.

8.questionText: Which of these healthcare providers might you need to see for your back pain?
8.explanation: Any of the above doctors may treat back pain. If the cause of your back pain is not known, you may need to see a neurologist. A rheumatologist can help if you have muscle or joint swelling or brittle bones.

8.questionText: Back pain can sometimes be a symptom of which of these conditions?
8.explanation: "Back pain can be a symptom for a number of health conditions, including disk problems, urinary tract infections, kidney stones, hernias and, in rare cases, even cancer. "

8.questionText: Doing what for 15 minutes three times a week can lower Alzheimer's risk by as much as 40 percent?
8.explanation: One study found that people who exercised for 15 minutes three times a week slashed Alzheimer's risk by as much as 40 percent. Researchers suspect that exercise protects the brain by promoting blood vessel health and boosting the brain's ability to repair damage.

9.questionText: Which of these is a possible treatment for back pain?
9.explanation: All of the above. The majority of patients with low back pain will see improvement with controlled physical activity, physical therapy, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and, in appropriate situations, muscle relaxants.

9.questionText: Eating which kind of chocolate can help you live longer?
9.explanation: Go for dark chocolate. People who eat dark chocolate have 30 percent less chance of heart disease and stroke.

9.questionText: Which of the following foods can add years to your life?
9.explanation: You've probably heard of an apple a day keeps the doctor away. Well you may want to substitute apple with onion. Onions lower LDL (bad cholesterol) which reduces the risk of heart attack and stroke. Onions are also rich in tocopherol, beta carotene and other protective compounds.

9.questionText: What spice can help you live longer?
9.explanation: Turmeric can help you live longer. Studies show turmeric has anti-inflammatory properties. It's also good for the cardiovascular system, improves immune and brain function, treats gastrointestinal problems, fights pain and prevents and fights certain cancers.

9.questionText: Which of these can cause hepatitis (liver inflammation)?
9.explanation: There are five main causes of hepatitis: viral infections and autoimmune disorders and disease, drug overdose, exposure to toxins and alcohol consumption. Depending upon the cause, symptoms can last from a few days to months (acute hepatitis) or grow progressively worse (chronic hepatitis).

9.questionText: Which of the following is true of hepatitis A?
9.explanation: Hepatitis A accounts for up to 25 percent of all hepatitis cases in developed countries. That's because hepatitis A is often transmitted through unclean food and water, so in countries with proper sanitation, hepatitis A is relatively rare. Hepatitis A infection usually clears up within a few weeks, although it could last up to six months or more. The good news: You can be infected only once in a lifetime.

answers.answerText: It is spread via unclean food or water.
One infection leads to lifelong immunity.
The infection usually goes away on its own.

9.questionText: Which of these is a true statement regarding hepatitis B?
9.explanation: Hepatitis B is a contagious viral infection of the liver spread by contact with bodily fluids. Most infections are acute lasting only weeks. There is no cure for hepatitis B.

answers.answerText: It is spread by contact with bodily fluids like blood and saliva.
There is a cure for hepatitis B.
Most cases of hepatitis B are chronic infections with symptoms lasting years. Ce

9.questionText: How should you treat a person who is bleeding externally?
9.explanation: If a person begins bleeding, cover the wound with a sterile dressing, and apply direct pressure until bleeding stops. Check for circulation (looking for feeling, warmth and color) around the injury.

answers.answerText: " Apply direct pressure until bleeding stops. "
" Check for circulation to make sure the bleeding problem is coming under control."
Cover the bleeding wound with a sterile dressing.

9.questionText: Which of these is a sign of internal bleeding?
9.explanation: Signs of internal bleeding include rapid, weak pulse; vomiting or coughing up blood; tender, swollen, bruised or hard areas of the body; skin that feels cool or moist, or looks pale or bluish; excessive thirst; a blue or extremely pale injured extremity; an altered mental state, such as becoming confused, faint, drowsy or unconscious. If you or someone else has any of these signs, seek immediate car

answers.answerText: Vomiting blood or coughing up blood
Tender, swollen, bruised or hard areas of the body, such as the abdomen

9.questionText: What is the best way to prevent flu?
9.explanation: According to the NHS, a flu shot is the best way to avoid the flu.

9.questionText: What fraction of employee absences are caused by stress and related conditions each year?
9.explanation: Work-related stress, depression or anxiety cause an average of 30 lost working days each year.

9.questionText: Which of these is a stress-management technique?
9.explanation: All of the above. Before you head home at the end of the day, take a few minutes to practice meditation or deep breathing. And take the scenic route home -- viewing natural scenery helps reduce stress and promote a healthy work-life balance.

9.questionText: How does exercise affect how you age?
9.explanation: " All of the above. Exercise boosts immunity, slows deterioration of the body and improves muscular strength and balance, all of which affect how we age."

9.questionText: What age group should do stretching exercises?
9.explanation: Everyone, no matter what their age, should include stretching exercises into their daily routine. Stretching improves flexibility, joint range of motion and strength as well as decreases injury risk.

9.questionText: Why do older people burn fewer calories?
9.explanation: Many 20-to-30-year-olds jog, play tennis and work out at health clubs. In later years, people are more likely to choose slower-paced activities like golf or bowling, which burn fewer calories

10.questionText: What type of exercises can prevent the onset of osteoporosis as you age?
10.explanation: As you age, weight-bearing exercise becomes extremely important to prevent the onset of osteoporosis

10.questionText: What is the difference in an over-50 fitness program?
10.explanation: Quality fitness programs for people over 50 are going to have many of the same components as programs for all other ages, but with some differences. These may include greater emphasis on flexibility, mobility, range of motion and exercises that promote greater ability to perform activities of daily living pain free or with greater ease.

answers.answerText: Greater emphasis on range of motion exercises
Greater emphasis on building muscle mass

10.questionText: Which of these does your pharmacist need to know?
10.explanation: You should give your pharmacist a list of all your medications, including prescriptions, over-the-counter (OTC) remedies and supplements. This will ensure that any prescription you're given is safe to take along with your current medications.

answers.answerText: All prescriptions you may be taking
Dietary supplements you may be taking
Over-the-counter medications you may be taking

10.questionText: Which of these questions can your pharmacist answer?
10.explanation: Your pharmacist can answer all of the above questions, as well as questions about dosage and a medication's purpose and intended effect

answers.answerText: What are the drug's side effects?
What should I do if I forget to take my medicine?

10.questionText: What are the consequences of information overload?
10.explanation: One of the consequences of information overload and increased technology at our fingertips is that more is happening at every given moment, making us feel that time moves faster. This leaves us feeling that there's never enough time to do things.

answers.answerText: Time feels like it moves faster

10.questionText: Which of these is a symptom of lupus?
10.explanation: All of the above. Symptoms of lupus include a butterfly-shaped rash over the cheeks and bridge of the nose, easy bruising, joint pain, fever, fatigue, weight loss or weight gain, mouth sores, skin lesions, chest pains and anxiety. People with lupus are also vulnerable to infection because the disease affects the immune system.

answers.answerText: Butterfly-shaped rash over the cheeks and bridge of the nose

10.questionText: Which of these factors causes lupus?
10.explanation: Doctors do not yet understand what causes lupus. But they suspect that lupus may occur as a result of both hereditary and environmental factor

answers.answerText: Doctors do not know what causes lupus

10.questionText: What percentage of caregivers have no additional help?
10.explanation: About 50 percent of caregivers have no additional help taking care of a loved one.

10.questionText: What is it the condition called when your second toe is longer than your big toe?
10.explanation: Morton’s Foot Syndrome, or Morton’s Toe, occurs when your metatarsal bones in the first toe are shorter than those in the second toe. While not serious, having Morton’s Toe can lead to arch pain and callusing or discomfort of the ball of the foot at the base of the second toe.

10.questionText: What is the smallest bone in the human body?
10.explanation: The smallest bone in the body is called the stapes bone, or the stirrup bone. One of three tiny bones in the middle ear that transmits sound to to the inner ear, it's only about 1/8-inch long in adults.

10.questionText: Someone who has excessive sweating in their palms, hands and feet suffers from what condition?
10.explanation: Hyperhidrosis is the name given to excessive and uncontrollable sweating. People with this condition typically have overactive sweat glands. Common areas where perspiration occurs: the face, underarms, hands and feet. Strong antiperspirants, Botox and sometimes surgery may remedy the conditi

10.questionText: Which of these organs is known for its regenerative powers?
10.explanation: The liver is the only organ that can regenerate itself fully after a large part of it is injured or removed. In fact, when part of the liver is removed for a transplant, the donor's and recipient's parts will grow to the normal size.

10.questionText: "Polydactyly" refers to a condition in which a person has extra
10.explanation: Polydactyly is a condition in which a person has more than five fingers or toes. These extra digits may be fully formed or just small attachments. Surgery is the most common treatment.

10.questionText: What does a nephrologist study?
10.explanation: A nephrologist is a doctor who specializes in kidney care. Neurologists study the nervous system (which includes the brain), pulmonologists focus on respiratory processes and cardiologists look at the heart and circulatory system.

10.questionText: Which of the following is a sign of heat stroke, the most serious heat-related disorder?
10.explanation: The signs of heat stroke include dry, red skin; confusion; and rapid, weak pulse. Additional signs include extremely high body temperature; changes in consciousness; rapid, shallow breathing; vomiting; and seizures.

10.questionText: What can you do to reduce your risk of cancer?
10.explanation: All of these can reduce your risk of cancer. What's more? Fighting belly bulge, getting regular exercise, and not overindulging in alcohol can also help you keep your risk of cancer -- and other diseases -- low.

answers.answerText: Eat a diet rich in fruits and vegetables

10.questionText: What percentage of cancer cases are preventable?
10.explanation: According to the World Health Organization, at least one-third (33%) of all cancer cases can be prevented.

10.questionText: Who should get the hepatitis B vaccine?
10.explanation: All of the above. The hepatitis B vaccine is recommended for all infants at birth and for adults who may be at increased risk.
